Eknath Easwaran: Selfish desire is found in the senses, mind, and intellect, misleading them and burying the understanding in delusion.
Mahatma Gandhi: The senses, the mind and the reason are said to be its great seat; by means of  these it obscures knowledge and stupefies man.
Shri Swami Purohit: It works through the senses, the mind and the reason; and with their help destroys wisdom and confounds the soul.

Eknath Easwaran: The goal of knowledge and the goal of service are the same; those who fail to see this are blind.
Mahatma Gandhi: The goal that the sankhyas attain is also reached by the yogins. He sees truly  who sees both sankhya and yoga as one.
Shri Swami Purohit: The level which is reached by wisdom is attained through right action as well. He who perceives that the two are one, knows the truth.

Eknath Easwaran: I will give you both jnana and vijnana. When both these are realized, there is nothing more you need to know.
Mahatma Gandhi: I will declare to you, in its entirety, this knowledge, combined with  discriminative knowledge, which when you have known there remains here  nothing more to be known.
Shri Swami Purohit: I will reveal to this knowledge unto you, and how it may be realised; which, once accomplished, there remains nothing else worth having in this life.

Eknath Easwaran: There are two paths, Arjuna, which the soul may follow at the time of death. One leads to rebirth and the other to liberation.
Mahatma Gandhi: Now I will tell you, Arjuna, the conditions which determine the  exemption from return, as also the return, of yogins after they pass away hence.
Shri Swami Purohit: Now I will tell you, O Arjuna, of the times at which, if the mystics go forth, they do not return, and at which they go forth only to return.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who worship me and meditate on me constantly, without any other thought  I will provide for all their needs.
Mahatma Gandhi: As for those who worship Me, thinking on Me alone and nothing else, ever  attached to Me, I bear the burden of getting them what they need.
Shri Swami Purohit: But if a man will meditate on Me and Me alone, and will worship Me always and everywhere, I will take upon Myself the fulfillment of his aspiration, and I will safeguard whatsoever he shall attain.

Eknath Easwaran: I am Ananta, the cosmic serpent, and Varuna, the god of water; I am Aryaman among the noble ancestors. Among the forces which restrain I am Yama, the god of death.
Mahatma Gandhi: Of cobras I am Anata; of water-dwellers I am Varuna; of the manes I am  Aryaman; and of the chastisers, Yama.
Shri Swami Purohit: I am the King-python among snakes, I am the Aqueous Principle among those that live in water, I am the Father of fathers, and among rulers I am Death.

Eknath Easwaran: O Lord, master of yoga, if you think me strong enough to behold it, show me your immortal Self.
Mahatma Gandhi: If, Lord, you thinks it possible for me to bear the sight, reveal to me, O  Krishna, Your imperishable form.  The Lord Said:
Shri Swami Purohit: If You think that it can be made possible for me to see it, show me, O Lord of Lords, Yours own Eternal Self.

Eknath Easwaran: Yet hazardous and slow is the path to the Unrevealed, difficult for physical creatures to tread.
Mahatma Gandhi: Greater is the travail of those whose mind is fixed on the Unmanifest; for it is  hard for embodied mortals to gain the Unmanifest—Goal.
Shri Swami Purohit: But they who thus fix their attention on the Absolute and Impersonal encounter greater hardships, for it is difficult for those who possess a body to realise Me as without one.

Eknath Easwaran: Those who strive resolutely on the path of yoga see the Self within. The thoughtless, who strive imperfectly, do not.
Mahatma Gandhi: Yogins who strive see Him seated in themselves; the witless ones who have  not cleansed themselves to see Him not, even though they strive.
Shri Swami Purohit: The saints with great effort find Him within themselves; but not the unintelligent, who in spite of every effort cannot control their minds.

Eknath Easwaran: Other qualities, Arjuna, make a person more and more inhuman: hypocrisy, arrogance, conceit, anger, cruelty, ignorance.
Mahatma Gandhi: Pretentiousness, arrogance, self-conceit, wrath, coarseness, ignorance—these  are to be found in one born with the devilish heritage.
Shri Swami Purohit: Hypocrisy, pride, insolence, cruelty, ignorance belong to him who is born of the godless qualities.

Eknath Easwaran: Disciplines practiced in order to gain respect, honor, or admiration are rajasic; they are undependable and transitory in their effects.
Mahatma Gandhi: Austerity which is practiced with an eye to gain praise, honour and homage  and for ostentation is said to be rajasa; it is fleeting and unstable.
Shri Swami Purohit: Austerity coupled with hypocrisy or performed for the sake of self-glorification, popularity or vanity, comes from Passion, and its result is always doubtful and temporary.
